Mr Luca Jellinek, bond strategist at Paribas in London, said: "Italian bonds made good gains on the back of strong domestic buying. 1999 was never a realistic target date for Italy's entrance to Emu, so the reports on its delayed but guaranteed entry could be taken as a positive development." Mr David Brown, chief economist at Bear Stearns in London, said: "The market's reaction was a little bit surprising. Italy is not off the hook at all. If Germany fails to give Italy less than resounding support at the summit between Mr Romano Prodi [prime minister of Italy] and Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Friday, then BTPs could take a dive." Traders said that the resolution of Italy's long-running metal-workers' wages dispute on Tuesday, and the slowing in the annual rate of growth of Italy's consumer price index to 2.6% - the lowest since 1969 - had fuelled expectations of further interest rate cuts by the central bank. The recovery of the lira on the foreign exchange markets, where it had dropped to L990 against the D-Mark in the morning but rose to L985 in the late afternoon, directly tracked the BTP rally. March futures on 10-year BTPs closed 0.83 higher at 130.55 on Liffe, while in the cash market the yield spread of BTPs over German bunds tightened to 155 basis points. Spanish bonos also recovered, in spite of yesterday's report by a government minister that Spain's public debt had risen by 4 percentage points in 1996 to 69.3% of GDP. Spanish 10-year bono futures rose by 0.23 to close at 113.39 in Barcelona. In the cash market, bonos' 10-year yield spread over bunds widened slightly to 109 basis points. Overnight profit-taking by Japanese investors after the appreciation of sterling helped push UK gilts lower after a one-week rally. Traders said Italian investors heavily offloaded gilt futures to realise their recent capital gains and take advantage of cheaper Italian bonds. Liffe's March long gilt future dropped 1/4 to close at 112 1/16. Yield spreads over 10-year bunds widened by six basis points to 174 basis points. German bund futures rose by 0.36 to settle at 102.15 on Liffe yesterday on expectations of a strong rise in January unemployment figures today. US Treasuries were moderately lower in mid-afternoon trading as the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. Bonds bounced briefly off their session lows just after 2pm, as the Fed announced that its Open Market Committee had not changed interest rates, and them began to settle back near their pre-announcement lows. Near 2.30pm, the benchmark 30-year Treasury was 3/8 lower at 96 to yield 6.731% and the two year note was down 1/32 to 99, yielding 5.874%. Few on Wall Street expected the FOMC to change monetary policy, although several economists expect an interest rate increase sometime in the first half of this year. Of more immediate concern to the market was the new supply to be sold next week as part of the Treasury's quarterly refunding operations. The Treasury said it planned to raise about $21.75bn next week through the sale of $17.75bn in three-year notes, $12bn in 10-year notes and $10bn in 30-year bonds. Copyright Financial Times Limited 1997. All Rights Reserved. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: Fed raises rates again and hints more to come.
content: LITTLE SIGN OF SLOWDOWN AS QUARTER POINT RISE TAKES KEY LENDING FIGURE TO 6%. The Federal Reserve redoubled its efforts to slow the pace of US economic growth yesterday with another quarter point increase in short-term interest rates. The central bank's open market committee raised its key lending rate to 6 per cent, and hinted there was more to come. It was the fifth time in nine months the fed funds target rate had been raised. The Fed's board also raised its largely symbolic discount rate by the same amount to 5.5 per cent. "Against the background of long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth ... the committee believes the risks are weighted toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future," the FOMC said. It remained concerned that increases in demand would "continue to exceed the growth in potential supply, which could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's record economic expansion". The latest increase sends short-term rates to their highest level since the spring of 1991, when the Fed began aggressively cutting them to stimulate recovery from the last recession. Financial markets had been expecting the increase and were largely unmoved. Since last June, the Fed has raised short-term rates by 1.25 percentage points, but has so far failed to damp the economy's fires. Gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 6.9 per cent in the last three months of 1999, and early data for the first quarter of this year suggest that, while growth is slowing somewhat, the pace remains well above 4 per cent. This is still in excess of what Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and his colleagues regard as a safe rate. Most economists expect another half point increase in rates, probably in two instalments beginning with the next FOMC meeting on May 16. What happens next will depend on whether the economy shows clear signs of a slowdown. Interest rate changes tend to work with relatively long time lags of up to a year, and there are now indications that the higher rates may be starting to bite into some sectors of the economy such as the housing market. Higher oil prices are also expected to damp demand. And in spite of a surge in prices of technology stocks over the past year, broader financial market indices are little changed on a year ago. Fed officials have said they are not targeting stock prices - but they believe increased equity market wealth has fed directly into faster rates of consumer spending growth. If there are no clear signs of a broader-based slowdown soon, the Fed may feel it needs to take more aggressive action, perhaps raising rates by more than the incremental, quarter-points it has made so far. Behind the Fed's gradual approach is uncertainty about the performance of the so-called "new economy". Most economists agree that technological and other changes have improved the economy's long-run performance, enabling it to grow faster without prompting inflation. But no-one can say what the new rate of sustainable growth is. Lex, Page 32 European technology stocks slide The slide in European technology stocks captured some high-profile victims yesterday, as recent internet debutants fell below their offer prices. Both World Online, the Dutch internet service provider, and Lastminute.com, which specialises in last-minute deals, closed beneath offer prices set last week. More established names also fell, including Tiscali of Italy, down more than 10 per cent to Euros 774.95 ( #474.23), and Terra Networks of Spain, down nearly 9 per cent at Euros 90.95. Report, Page 43. Copyright Financial Times Limited 2000. All Rights Reserved.

headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR - No company is immune to interest rate levels.
content: From Dr Richard Hadfield. Sir, I am always intrigued by the notion that some companies are immune to interest rate levels. No companies are so fortunate. It is suggested that the FOMC, the US Federal Reserve's interest rate setting committee, will force the "old economy" into recession before technology stocks will be affected ("American business feels the squeeze", March 21). I would argue that the first companies to feel recession will be those currently relying on private equity funding rather than those already borrowing money. There will be a rate level at which investors will rather receive guaranteed income than vague promises of future earnings and at that point the new equity process will dry up. The old economy's interest expense will have increased monotonically with the interest rate whilst the new economy's interest expense will be more step-function in nature, from zero to actual. At that point, the old economy may be straining but the new economy will suffer worse as it suddenly has to borrow money from lenders wanting interest payments, not stock options. Richard Hadfield, Vice President, DKB Financial Products (HK), 32nd floor, Gloucester Tower, Landmark, 11 Pedder Street, Central, Hong Kong. Copyright Financial Times Limited 2000. All Rights Reserved.

headline: Fed urged to curb margin requirements.
content: The Federal Reserve should consider raising margin requirements, instead of interest rates, to remedy its concerns about share valuations, urged economists and lawmakers yesterday at a congressional hearing. The testimony before a House of Representatives banking subcommittee pointedly questioned why the Fed's concerns for skyrocketing technology shares could not be better handled by curbing the flow of borrowed money into the market. The testimony echoed a rising Wall Street concern that the Fed's use of interest rates to cool the stock market could do more harm than good in the long run. In the meantime, the Fed's policymaking Federal Open Market Committee raised its key interest rate yesterday for the fifth time in nine months to 6 per cent. The Fed has not changed the margin requirement, currently 50 per cent, since 1974. Stocks bought on margin, or with borrowed money, rose 8.9 per cent in February and 6.5 per cent in January. Overall, margin debt has reached $265bn, and risen by $83bn since last October. Since it appears that the Fed's goal is to temper the stock market to ease consumer spending fostered by the wealth effect, panellists testified a rise in margin requirements might be a more precise instrument. "Why not use a scalpel instead of a sledgehammer," said Charles Schumer, a US senator from New York, who hoped a study by the Fed and the Securities and Exchange Commission could help crystallise the issue with its release in a month. Alan Greenspan, Fed chairman, has argued there is no direct correlation between margin changes and share prices. Others argue that margin increases hurt smaller investors, who are an increasing user of borrowed money to finance investments. Many market observers have credited the Nasdaq's recent rise to a surge in borrowing to buy stocks. Moreover, it raises concerns that a sudden drop in the market could prompt investors to sell shares to cover margin calls, which could potentially send the market reeling. Copyright Financial Times Limited 2000. All Rights Reserved.

headline: GOVERNMENT BONDS - TREUHAND AUCTION GIVES IMPETUS TO BUND INVESTORS.
content: A WELL-RECEIVED bond auction in Germany provided an impetus for bund investors yesterday. The DM 4.25bn auction of bonds issued by Treuhand, the state agency responsible for privatising companies in the former east Germany, resulted in an accepted bid price of 99.49 and a yield of 6.7%. There was no official statement of the demand but dealers said it was well-covered with considerable domestic interest. Traders said investors were selling bund futures to buy the Treuhand bonds, which form part of a DM 10bn issue announced on Tuesday. The sale was the main factor in a generally quiet day with no signals coming from the repo rate announcement - the variable rate was left unchanged at 7.3% - and little indication that the Bundesbank intended to cut rates when it next meets on July 15. However, economists hope to glean some information from the next money supply growth figures, due at that central bank meeting. The last M3 figure of 6.7% was above the central bank's target range and if next week's figure is within the range there is a greater chance of a further monetary easing at the final council meeting before the summer break on July 29. Futures selling to buy the Treuhand bond saw the bund contract for September lose earlier gains and close only 2 basis points higher at 95.39. THE UK government bond market ran out of steam yesterday as both sterling and gilts had been considered overbought. With no economic data on the horizon and the tap of 9% stock dated 2008 said to be finally exhausted, the gilts market drifted. Any support that it received was psychological and came from overseas. Gilt futures for September were down on the previous close but 1/8 up on the day. FRENCH government bonds held steady yesterday despite a growing belief that they have hit a short-term high and are ripe for profit-taking. Bond prices were helped by a slightly stronger franc, which recovered from recent weakness against the D-Mark. The yield spread between French and German 10-year government bonds remained very low, closing at 6 basis points, according to JP Morgan. On the Matif, September futures rose 0.18 to 119.78. JAPANESE debt prices were weaker in Tokyo as the Bank of Japan sought to pour cold water on increasingly heated rate cut rumours. Speculation has gathered pace that the central bank will cut its official discount rate, presently at 2 1/4%, by as much as 50 basis points. Although it is considered unlikely that the bank will ease before the general election on July 18, traders have been busily discounting any change. At its money market operations yesterday, the central bank provided far less supply than expected and forced short-term rates higher. The yield on the JGB No 145, which has been below 4.3% in the past few days, rose to 4.35% and when Japanese bond futures began trading in London, the September contract slipped 7 basis points to 109.13. Following comments from a Japanese government official that the pain threshold for Japanese exporters could be Y 95 to Y 105 against the dollar, the September contract recovered to close at 109.30. AFTER posting early gains on cheaper commodities, US Treasuries fell back as commodity prices retraced their steps. In late trading the benchmark 30-year government bond was down 1/32 at 105 11/32, yielding 6.679%. At the short end of the market, the two-year note was unchanged at 100 7/32, to yield 3.992%. After Tuesday's steep rise in the Commodity Research Bureau index had deflated Treasury prices, yesterday morning's retreat in the index prompted some buying among market participants, mostly the professional dealers. Treasuries fell back from their early gains, however, when the CRB index began to recover. Otherwise, attention was focused on the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, which was meeting to discuss monetary policy. Although the rise in the CRB index raised some fears that the FOMC would keep its strategy tilted towards tightening monetary policy, most analysts believe it will vote to return the bias to neutral in the wake of weak employment data. (c) The Financial Times Limited 1993.

headline: LEADER - Fed's misplaced caution.
content: For now, at least, Alan Greenspan, the US Federal Reserve chairman, is content to stick to his guns. The Federal Open Market Committee maintained its 1 3/4 per cent target for the federal funds rate, although it has become considerably more cautious about US economic prospects since it last met in June. Then it described monetary policy as "accommodative" and said that on the "information currently available", the risks to price stability and sustainable economic growth were "balanced". Now it admits that the weakness in aggregate demand has been "prolonged" and the "the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness". The Fed's stance is somewhat strange. On the information now available, the economy is considerably weaker than was thought at the time of the last FOMC meeting and ominous clouds have appeared on the horizon. In June, the Fed thought economic activity was increasing at a healthy pace but we now know that growth slowed sharply in the second quarter. The economy grew at an annualised rate of just 1.1 per cent. To this, the Fed must add the weakness of equity markets since July, which will severely weaken household balance sheets, and the prospects of a rebound in corporate investment. On their own, these two changes are enough to render the Fed's forecast of 3 1/2 per cent to 3 3/4 per cent economic growth in 2002 all but impossible to achieve. Prospects for 2003 have also dimmed. Consistency would suggest that as the facts have changed, so should interest rates. Instead, the Fed's reluctance to do more than change its assessment of economic prospects suggests it feared really spooking financial markets. It is an unfortunate irony that the Fed recently published and promoted an internal working paper on the lessons from Japan's experience in the 1990s. The paper convincingly concluded that as Japan's economy turned down from 1990 onward and as interest rates and inflation approached zero, both monetary and fiscal policy should have responded with greater vigour than usual. Although US monetary policy responded with much greater speed to the first signs of recession last year than did the Bank of Japan in the early 1990s, it seems that the Fed's willingness to learn those lessons is waning. The risks to US economic prospects are uneven. While a double-dip recession is a distinct possibility and could start a vicious circle of consumer retrenchment, declining confidence and further output cuts, the risks associated with somewhat higher inflation are minimal. The Fed missed a trick yesterday. It should reconsider when the FOMC meets again on September 24. London Edition 1.

headline: STOCK MARKETS LONDON STOCK EXCHANGE - Equities dip, then rally ahead of US rate news.
content: It was another difficult session in London's equity market until the final hour of trading, when a strong rally on Wall Street prompted a similar trend in UK stocks and left all the main indices in good heart at the close. The UK's benchmark index, the FTSE 100, ended a session of surprisingly brisk activity a net 50.1 higher at 4,271.7, having been down 59.1 at 4,162.5 an hour before the US market opened for the day. Before the late rally, sentiment in London had taken another knock ahead of the outcome of last night's meeting of the US Federal Reserve's open market committee and after some disappointing domestic economic news. Fears that the committee would leave US interest rates on hold, while shifting to an easing bias because of a weakening US economy and a deteriorating earnings outlook, triggered further pockets of profit-taking among many of the FTSE 100's constituents for much of the session. There was little enthusiasm in markets, either, after some as-expected news on US retail sales. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost more than 80 points early in the US session, before rallying to show a 56-point gain before London traders closed their dealing books. Adding to the market's initial problems was a handful of bearish stories in the utilities sector, normally one of the most defensive areas in underperforming markets. The performances from second and third-tier stocks, even when the leaders were being punished, gave market bulls cause for optimism. The FTSE 250 index was never under that much pressure, in spite of disturbing falls in British Energy and Waste Recycling. The midcap index ended 21.6 firmer at 4,723.1. The FTSE SmallCap, meanwhile, was always in positive territory and finished the day with a 5.9 gain at 2,008.4. The bearish domestic economic news came with the July retail price index data, which came in higher than the market had expected. The core figure was up 2 per cent, year-on-year, compared with a consensus forecast of 1.8 per cent. Jonathan Loynes, chief UK economist at Capital Economics, said: "While the numbers are clearly a little disappointing, they are certainly not a disaster. "After holding at about 2 per cent next month, RPIX should fall back for the rest of this year and next." The global economics team at ING Financial Markets said: "There is little likelihood of a move in UK rates any time soon." Rather surprisingly, given the potential for shocks from the FOMC after the market closed, turnover in the equities market picked up strongly to reach 2.4bn shares, boosted by programme trading and exceptionally heavy business in Vodafone. The latter accounted for about 16 per cent of overall market volume. London Edition 1.

headline: Gerard Baker - A profit warning to America.
content: Washington, August 14, 2002 I, George W. Bush, being the chief executive officer of the United States government, do hereby certify that the account I have given of my government's financial performance in the recent reporting period is an accurate and fair picture of our operations. In accordance with new rules that take effect today, I fully understand that this certification carries with it personal legal liability. Accordingly, it has been necessary for me, in the course of reviewing previous accounts of my government's financial performance, to make a number of material restatements of earlier operating estimates, forecasts and accounting policies and guidelines. To wit: o 1 - My senior officials and I stated last year that our budget proposals, notably a $1,700bn (GBP1,080bn) 10-year tax cut, were prudent and would ensure fiscal stability over the medium term. We said the US would, even after the tax cut, still record a surplus of almost $4,000bn over the next 10 years. Furthermore, we insisted that, in line with best accounting practice, we had no plans to spend the surplus in the Social Security Trust fund, the country's pension fund. It now seems, regrettably, that the surpluses we confidently projected a year ago have disappeared faster than documents at an Arthur Andersen shredding party. About four-fifths of the 10-year surplus has gone. And we can only get to any kind of surplus at all if we make fanciful assumptions about spending (how does an increase of 1.5 per cent per year sound?) and taxes (no renewal of tax breaks that will terminate by law in the next few years). Further, there is no way now to pay for the tax cut without raiding the pension fund. If we didn't use the pension money, we would be looking at a 10-year deficit of about $2,000bn, which is about the same size as the tax cut. But after consultation with our auditors (Karl Rove LLP), we have decided we have no obligation to take any action to rectify these problems, which, despite our commitment to personal responsibility and integrity, we blame entirely on others. We suggest any questions about the resolution of these accounting issues be directed to Thomas A. Daschle, US Senate. o 2 - I claimed repeatedly this year that I said during my campaign for chief executive in 2000 that I would accept a fiscal deficit only in the case of war, recession or a national emergency; and, lucky me, I got all three. It now appears that there is no evidence to support the claim that I said any such thing. o 3 - I said, as recently as Tuesday of this week, at the President's Economic Forum in Waco, Texas, that the US economy was on a firm footing. It now appears that more authoritative and independent assessments of our trading conditions (cf Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, statement of the Federal Open Market Committee, the same day) actually suggest the economy is weakening and could be in a hole. o 4 - My chief financial officer, Paul H. O'Neill (who is available to answer all questions on this certification) said on September 17 last year that the stock market would recover its losses and soon be establishing new records. It now appears that, with the Standard and Poor's index of 500 stocks currently 38 per cent below its peak, and investors having lost $1,700bn on their wealth, his comments may have been about as helpful to our investors as Jack Grubman's "Buy" recommendations for WorldCom stock. o 5 - Last year and earlier this year Mr O'Neill made various statements to the effect that the "plumbers and carpenters of America" would not pour their money into suspect Latin American governments so that it could be siphoned straight off into "Swiss bank accounts". It now appears that the decisions to support international lending of $8bn to Argentina, $30bn to Brazil, and a direct US loan to Uruguay were a prudent use of taxpayers' money, and a wise investment. We reject any notion that there could be a "moral hazard" risk in our advancing such large loans and we stand ready to provide similar support wherever it is needed. o 6 - Richard B. Cheney, the chairman of the board (who has declined to make himself available for this certification), stated in a speech in San Francisco last week: "We are glad that Congress came together to pass the president's corporate integrity proposals." On closer examination, we understand that the bill passed by Congress last month was in fact, the bill drawn up by a political opponent, one Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, that I offered no support for this bill whatsoever until it was clear it was going to pass with no opposition, and to say it was "my bill" is about as reliable a statement as Kenneth Lay's assurance last autumn that Enron had sound long-term prospects. o 7 - On a number of occasions, I may have misled investors in the United States and overseas about the basis on which my government would conduct international trade policy, in particular when I said last year (passim) that free trade was in "America's best interests". Following my imposition of tariffs on world steel and Canadian lumber, I now wish to restate the basis on which US trade policy will be conducted. It is to be conducted on a simple calculation of what is most likely to get me re-elected in electorally tight steel-and wood-producing states in the north east and north west. o 8 - On a number of occasions I may have misled investors in the United States and overseas about my government's approach to subsidies and public spending. I said I would not support large increases in spending, especially to subsidise inefficient operations. Following my decision to support a $150bn package of support for farmers, I now wish to restate the basis on which fiscal policy will be conducted. It will be conducted on a simple calculation of what is most likely to get me re-elected in electorally tight farm states in the mid-west and the south. I believe that these restatements faithfully reflect the condition of my government. Wheretofore I place my seal, this 14th day of August 2002. George W. Bush Signed in his absence on holiday in Crawford, Texas, by Donald H. Rumsfeld, acting chief executive, United States government Harvey, is this what you were looking for? Don gerard.baker@ft.com.

headline: Volatile trading after Fed leaves rates at 2%
content: GLOBAL OVERVIEW Other central banks tighten policies Investors heartened by falling oil price There was volatile trading in US Treasury bonds, equities and the dollar yesterday after the Federal Reserve expressed concern about inflation and kept investors guessing about rate rises later this year. As expected the Fed kept its overnight rate steady at 2 per cent, and brought to an end a series of rate cuts that started last September. Richard Fisher, president of the Dallas Fed dissented and sought a rate increase. The Fed's policy statement policy makers read in part: "Although downside risks to growth remain, they appear to have diminished somewhat, and the upside risks to inflation and inflation expectations have increased." Stephen Stanley, chief economist at RBS Greenwich Capital said: "The Federal Open Market Committee chose to talk about how conditions have changed but not about their leanings. What the committee was unwilling to say for a second straight meeting is which set of risks predominates." The Fed, also noted that "labour markets have softened further and financial markets remain under considerable stress." Given falling house prices and higher energy costs, investors believe the Fed faces a difficult job balancing its twin objectives of sustaining economic growth and containing inflation. William Strazzullo, market strategist at Bell Curve Trading, said: "In the end it comes down to growth for the Fed, rather than inflation. I find it hard to believe the Fed will tighten when the unemployment rate is rising." Other central bankers were also in the spotlight yesterday as Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, clarified his recent remarks about a rate hike when the ECB meets on July 3. "I said we could decide to move our rates by a small amount in our next meeting in order to secure the solid anchoring of inflation expectations," Mr Trichet said. Norway's central bank raised its key interest rate by 25 basis points to 5.75 per cent in response to higher inflation and confounded the view of some economists who had expected no change. That came after India tightened policy on Tuesday to counter inflation, running above 11 per cent. US government bond prices weakened in a knee-jerk fashion after traders heard from the Fed and then rebounded sharply. The yield on the two-year note topped out at 3 per cent and then plunged down to 2.81 per cent as traders trimmed the chances of a rate hike in August. The market is pricing in a funds rate just above 2.50 per cent by the end of the year. The yield on the 10-year note was steady around 4.11 per cent after a brief spike to 4.18 per cent in post-Fed trade. Bond yields in the UK fell, led by a 8bp drop in the two-year gilt to 5.21 per cent. UK retail sales were negative in June according to the Confederation of British Industry. European bond yields rose after Mr Trichet's remarks. European and US equity markets rallied as oil prices slumped earlier yesterday. The FTSE Eurofirst 300 index closed up 1.1 per cent, while in London the FTSE 100 rallied 0.6 per cent. The S&P 500 index closed up 0.6 per cent in New York, and pared a 1.6 per cent gain after the Fed news. US corporate credit spreads moved wider. Asian equity markets were mixed, with export companies lower after weak US data on Tuesday. Japan's Nikkei 225 index fell 0.1 per cent, while in an abbreviated session, Hong Kong rose 0.8 per cent. Taiwan fell 0.2 per cent and Korea rallied 0.4 per cent. Shanghai rose 3.6 per cent and closed higher for the second day in a row. India's Sensex closed 0.8 per cent higher after rebounding from an early slide of 1.9 per cent. Pakistan's Karachi Stock Exchange 100 index rose a further 2.5 per cent, extending Tuesday's 8.6 per cent gain. In currency trading , action and words from central banks dictated moves. The dollar slipped after the Fed meeting as the euro was boosted by the ECB's tougher talk on rates. Norway's krone gained against both the euro and dollar and India's rupee hit a three-week high versus the dollar. Trading was also volatile in crude oil prices . US oil inventories rose for the first time in six weeks. At one stage, oil fell more than $5 a barrel, before it pared some of its losses to settle at $134.55.

headline: Dow rallies after Fed pegs rate.
content: Wall Street was cheered by yesterday's decision not to raise interest rates, writes Jane Martinson in New York. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed not far from its all-time high with a 74.58 increase to 7,303.46. The market had initially reacted with enthusiasm before falling off. Most of the gains were then made in the last hour of trading. Mr David Shulman, chief strategist at Solomon Brothers, echoed other bullish commentators when he said: "The Fed has given the green light to the stock market." The decision by the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, announced yesterday afternoon, had a more positive impact on stock prices than on the bond market, which was relatively muted. The benchmark 30-year bond rose 5/16 to 96 9/16 although it had fallen during the afternoon on fears about a rates increase in July. Other analysts believed that the Fed should have raised rates to slow recent fast growth. Mr Byron Wein, US strategist at Morgan Stanley, said: "The bond market is smarter than the stock market". He said it was too soon to say what the long-term effect of the decision would be, although he predicted a difficult summer. Analysts had been more than usually divided over the possible outcome of the FOMC meeting, although the bond market appeared to have factored in no change. The enthusiastic response was widespread. The technology-driven Nasdaq composite index rose 22.64 or 1.7% to 1,363.88, while the broader based S&P 500 gained 8.39 to 841.66. Financial blue chips rallied strongly after the decision, having suffered from some uncertainty in morning trade. J.P. Morgan rose 2.7% to $105 1/4 while Travelers Group gained $1 7/8 or 3.4% to $57 7/8. IBM rose almost 3% or $4 3/4 to $173 1/2, helped by a positive broker's note. Ford, the motor giant, also benefited from rumours of an upbeat analysts presentation and the possibility of a share buy-back. It rose $1 or 2.8% to $37 3/8. Even Informix, the troubled database company which has lost almost half its share price value, rose 4% or $3/8 to $9 5/16 in the upbeat market. It had fallen sharply in recent weeks. However, C-Cube Microsystems lost 22% or $5 5/8 to $19 7/8 as the company warned of lower than expected second-quarter earnings. TORONTO closed higher after a late afternoon rally sparked by Wall Street. The 300 composite index rose 12.76 or 0.20% to 6,260.14. Declines slightly outpaced advances 482 to 475. Trading volume was 83.2m shares, down from Friday's total of 88.7m. Trading value rose to C$1.52bn from C$1.36bn. The golds sub-index weighed on the market, falling 0.34%. Franco Nevada slipped 45 cents at C$69.35. Bank of Montreal added 25 cents to C$53.40 and Royal Bank of Canada gained 15 cents at C$59.40. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: Yen rises as Fed makes no move.
content: The dollar tumbled further late yesterday after the Federal Reserve left US interest rates unchanged following its Open Market committee meeting. The dollar, which had already fallen sharply in overnight Asian trading, immediately dropped another Y 0.75 on news of the meeting to stand at Y 112.95 against the yen. That was Y 3.25 below its Monday London close. The Fed's announcement sent the dollar falling 1.3 pfennigs against the D-Mark to DM 1.6860, 2.1 pfennigs down on Monday's close. The yen had surged even before the FOMC meeting, on fresh signs that Japan might raise interest rates soon. The currency jumped to Y 112 against the dollar after Mr Koko Sato, a senior member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic party, said there was growing political support for a rise in interest rates. Low rate levels were "negatively affecting pensioners and could also invite further fund outflow from the domestic financial market to high-yielding overseas assets." A panel of LDP politicians is due to issue a report within days which will indicate that the low rate climate may also be distorting the financial system. The Bank of Japan's official discount rate has stood at a record trough of 0.5% since September 1995. The markets largely ignored an attempt by Mr Taku Yamasaki, chairman of the LDP's policy research council, to play down Mr Sato's remark. Mr Yamasaki said now was not the time to discuss the possibility of a rate rise. Also yesterday, the Japanese trade union confederation said it would soon formally ask the Bank of Japan for a rate rise because low interest rates were hurting pensioners and savers. The dollar came under further pressure after Mr Robert Rubin, US treasury secretary, repeated that Washington's policy towards the currency was unchanged but failed to reel off his usual mantra that the US supported a strong dollar. The yen has now gained almost Y 15 or 12% against the dollar in the last fortnight, on hopes of a Japanese rate rise and attempts by Tokyo officials to talk down the dollar. The same officials are now trying to support the US currency. Yesterday Mr Eisuke Sakakibara, the senior finance ministry official known as Mr Yen, said: "The pace of the yen's strengthening is too rapid." Japan would "deal appropriately" with excessive volatility. That boosted the dollar somewhat. The dollar's slide buoyed the Swiss franc, largely because many traders had funded dollar purchases by borrowing the Swiss currency at low interest rates. The Swissie rose from SwFr 1.428 to SwFr 1.406 against the dollar, and from SwFr 0.837 to SwFr 0.830 against the D-Mark in London. * Mr Ron Leven, currency strategist at J.P. Morgan in New York, believes the dollar may stop sliding sooner than many in the market think. The reason, he says, is that many Japanese investors are hedging rather than selling their overseas assets. For instance, rather than disposing of their US Treasuries and repatriating the income, they are selling dollars forward. That means that if they change their view on the yen, they can return to overseas markets simply by buying dollars forward for the same period. "If the Japanese had left the US market completely, it would be much more difficult for them to come back in again," Mr Leven said. * Mr Paul Chertkow, head of global foreign exchange research at UBS in London, warned that the dollar could fall through support at Y 110 against the yen soon because the market no longer believed the US currency had much upside. The only way Japan could boost the dollar would be by changing policy, he said. Tokyo could hardly cut interest rates, so it would have to encourage Japanese life companies to increase their holdings of overseas assets again, and also to buy Japanese bonds in order to reduce their yields. If the dollar did bounce, many Japanese investors would quickly sell it in order to cut their losses on its recent slide, said Mr Chertkow. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: US Treasuries rise as Fed sits tight.
content: The US Treasury market greeted the Federal Reserve's decision not to change interest rates with enthusiasm yesterday. The benchmark 30-year bond rose 5/16 to 96 9/16, yielding 6.892%. Uncertainty about the longer-term outlook appeared to put pressure on prices after the immediate euphoria had worn off, however. Prices at the long end had fallen during the afternoon. Some strategist were surprised at the muted reaction in bond prices, which was much less bullish about the decision than the stock market. Volumes were also relatively low. Mr Kevin Logan, senior market economist at Kleinwort Dresdner Benson, said the reaction indicated that the Fed had not been expected to raise rates after a raft of economic data had pointed to slightly weaker growth rates. "The people who place the bets appeared to expect no change, despite opinion among analysts being divided," he said. He predicted a continuation of market sensitivity in the run-up to the next meeting of the Federal Reserve's open market committee in six weeks time. "I don't expect it to rally too far," he said. "After this meeting people will start thinking about July." Mr Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said the markets were likely to continue to "have a bumpy ride", reacting to each piece of economic data until the next Fed meeting. Yield curves steepened after the news. The two-year note rose 1/8 to 100 5/16 yielding 6.182% and the yield spread between the two-year and 30-year securities widened from about 65 basis points to 71 basis points. European government bond markets trod water yesterday waiting for the outcome of the Fed committee meeting. FRENCH OATs were the only leading European bonds to give any ground, settling at the day's low of 129.64, down 0.24 on Monday's close. Analysts said there was little to explain the drift downwards. "There's been some profit-taking ahead of the FOMC. Some minor positions have been liquidated," said Mr Philip Tyson, European bond analyst at HSBC. "Other than that, everyone was content to remain on the sidelines." UK GILTS barely moved, in spite of a big turn-out for the auction of #1.5bn of 7% 2002 stock. Cover was 3.03 times and there was no yield tail. "We expected a tail of a couple of basis points so we were pleasantly surprised," said Mr Edmund Nonis, gilts analyst at Nikko Securities. The auction was small, however, and Mr Nonis warned about reading too much into it. The June long gilt future settled at 113 15/32, up 1/32 on the day. In the cash market the 10-year yield spread of gilts over bunds tightened 3 basis points to 142 points. Preliminary May inflation data from five Italian cities was in line with expectations and elicited few reactions from ITALIAN BTPs. Having jumped to 131.02, the June BTP future settled at 103.89, up 0.12 on the day. The 10-year yield spread of BTPs over bunds tightened 4 basis points to 137 points. May inflation figures from a further six Italian cities are due today. Yesterday's figures suggested that Italian annual inflation would slow to 1.5% in May, down from 1.7% in April, analysts said. Traders in SPANISH BONOS were taken aback by a late rally which coincided with the sudden rise in Italian BTPs. "I was a bit surprised ... maybe it was just one buyer," said Mr Jose Ramon Arechederra of ABN Amro in Madrid. Bonos eventually settled at 116.08, up 0.41 on the day. The 10-year yield spread of bonos over bunds touched a new low of 69 basis points before settling at 70 basis points. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: EQUITY FUTURES AND OPTIONS TRADING.
content: An already weak derivatives sector came under further pressure yesterday as concerns about US interest rates combined with a sharp fall in defence-related stocks to prompt a sell-off in stock index futures, writes Joel Kibazo. Hopes of a recovery after the June contract on the FTSE 100 opened for business at 4,654, faded when strong selling emerged within the first hour of the session. June, which just managed to touch 4,658, retreated sharply. An attempt to stabilise it around the 4,650 level proved fruitless. June continued to fall, breaking through the 4,620 resistance level over lunch, on its way to the day's low. That was reached after the poor opening on Wall Street when the contract fell to 4,601. Dealers said the decline of defence stocks had come as a surprise to a market already nervous about US interest rates ahead of the outcome of the FOMC meeting. One trader said: "The buyers are still around but they are simply waiting their turn." Some buying interest was seen towards the close as the contract recovered from the day's low. It closed at 4,610, down 47 on its previous close and at a 3 point premium to the underlying cash market. Dealers said the contract had traded at a discount to cash on several occasions during the course of the session. Volume was 12,514 contracts. There was improved activity in traded options and turnover nearly doubled to reach 44,922. Most of the activity was in index options with BT the busiest stock option. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: Rate worries, company news hit bourses.
content: Interest rate uncertainty hit the dollar and equities in Europe ahead of yesterday's FOMC meeting; some late closing bourses, back from a long weekend, were also digesting the third fall in the Dow in three consecutive days; and the effect was compounded where there was bad corporate news. FRANKFURT, with bad news among blue chips and in the mid-cap sector of the market, put it all together and fell 1.5%, the Dax index closing 53.06 lower at an Ibis-indicated 3,516.20, in turnover down from DM 13.8bn to DM 11.2bn. Cyclicals, primarily carmakers and chemicals, were predisposed to fall on the dollar; but BASF led the big blue chips down on news of a billion-dollar lawsuit against Knoll, its US-based pharmaceuticals unit. It lost DM 2.60 or just under 4% at DM 63.25. Hoechst was right behind, down DM 2.50 at DM 64.85, and Volkswagen closed DM 32.50 lower at DM 1,115.50. However, there was worse in mid-caps where Gerresheimer, the glassmaking subsidiary of Viag, plummeted DM 9.90 or 27.6% to DM 26; the company forecast a fall in operating profits this year due to price pressures in container glass. A month ago, said Mr Stefan Muelheim at Dillon Read, Gerresheimer had attributed a slide in first quarter profits to one-off problems. Now, he said, earnings hopes of DM 2.80 to DM 3 a share, after last year's DM 2.35, would have to be written off, and the shares were a sell. PARIS swept lower with the CAC 40 index retreating 33.17 to 2,751.11 after touching a session low of 2,731.17. Volume was said to be average at 11.9m shares. US rate uncertainty and the soft start on Wall Street did most of the damage, but renewed election jitters, some downside pressure from ex-dividends and disquieting news from LVMH also hit sentiment. The luxury goods giant did its best to smooth over the failure of its newly acquired DFS operation to win two Hong Kong airport concessions, but the shares took little notice, sliding FFr 41 or 2.8% to FFr 1,447. Total paid more attention to the softening oil price than to an upgrade from Goldman Sachs which moved to "market outperform". The shares came off FFr 5 to FFr 553, as Elf Aquitaine dipped FFr 9 to FFr 592. Motors were out of favour. Renault fell FFr 3.10 or 2% to FFr 153.9 and Peugeot FFr 10 to FFr 646. Accor, the hotels leader, stood out against the selling pressure, adding FFr 11 at FFr 889. ZURICH was depressed by the dollar and the Dow, and a string of index heavyweights came under pressure as the SMI index dropped 76.5 or 1.5% to 5,081.0. Novartis bearers lost SwFr 46 at SwFr 1,973, Roche certificates SwFr 290 at SwFr 13,205 and Nestle registered SwFr 39 at SwFr 1,818. However, the real pain was in other well-known names: Julius Baer, the banking group, was cut from "buy" to "hold" by CS First Boston after recent out-performance and fell SwFr 59 to SwFr 1,971; and Schindler, the maker of lifts and escalators, dropped SwFr 127 or 6.6% to SwFr 1,788. Mr Matthew Windridge, head of research at Standard &Poors MarketScope, noted that Schindler was up 68% since its low last July, and 28% since S &P's own buy note on Schindler only three months ago, which took in a target price of SwFr 1,850. AMSTERDAM ended off 6.85 at 787.45 on the AEX index. A handful of stocks made upward progress, notably Nedlloyd ahead of today's results and ING following publication of its US listing prospectus. Nedlloyd rose 70 cents to Fl 48.80 and ING added 40 cents at Fl 80.10. But the broad market came under pressure. Aegon lost Fl 3 to Fl 140.70 and KLM, which puts out results today, fell 80 cents to Fl 58.20. Speculation that Unilever was poised to launch a major US takeover left the shares off Fl 7.50 at Fl 377.90. Among smaller capitalisation stocks, Baan slipped Fl 3.40 to Fl 108.80 in spite of a buy note from HSBC James Capel predicting sales growth this year of 63% for the software group. MILAN threw caution to the wind and opted for a modest upward movement on talk of a cut for interest rates, possibly today should May's preliminary CPI data prove positive. The Mibtel index hardened 8 to 12,435. Ambroveneto, winner in the race to link up with Cariplo, the big savings bank, fell L296 to L4,125 on worries about a capital increase to finance the deal. But there were steady gains elsewhere. BCI, which also bid for Cariplo, improved L29 to L3,585 and Edison gained L123 to L8,155. MADRID was the major exception to the day's downtrend, the general index closing 5.70 higher at 547.56, with turnover up from Pta40.51bn to Pta119.55bn on news that Morgan Stanley had upgraded Spain's weighting from 3% to 4.5% in its European model portfolio. Mr Richard Davidson, Morgan's European equity strategist, said he had been growing increasingly convinced that Spain would be in the first group of countries joining in European monetary union in 1999. Endesa, the broker's choice, rose Pta230 or 2.1% to Pta11,330. VIENNA registered a new all-time closing high, the ATX index coming in 19.05 or 1.5% better at 1,270.36. OMV, the oil and chemicals group, rose Sch98.20 or 6.8% to Sch1,535 on continued investment interest. ISTANBUL put on 1.2% ahead of an acrimonious censure vote in parliament against the Islamist-led coalition government, the IMKB National-100 index closing 18 higher at 1,510. ATHENS had been waiting a long time to set a new all-time high; and although it got there in early trading - with an intra-day peak of 1,695.03, its best since July, 1990 - the mere fact of it was taken as a signal for profit-taking. The general index ended more than 70 points off the top, 48.52 or 2.9% down on the day at 1,621.71, in high turnover of Dr41.5bn. Written and edited by William Cochrane and Jeffrey Brown. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: Mexico City stronger.
content: Leading Latin American centres responded positively to the Fed's decision to leave US interest rates unchanged. MEXICO CITY rose and the peso strengthened immediately after the announcement. "A lot of buying suddenly appeared," said one equities trader. The IPC index shot ahead, then fell back slightly to record a gain of 0.6% or 25.20 at 3,946.93. BUENOS AIRES also pushed sharply higher, the Merval index gaining 7.22 or 1% at 751.89. The Merval had been about 0.2% stronger before the FOMC statement. SAO PAULO traded sideways ahead of the US announcement. At midsession, the Bovespa index was 80 lower at 10,426. Telmex hardened slightly to R$17.26 following a national carrier pact with Global One, the Deutsche Telekom, France Telecom and Sprint joint venture. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: Dow surges after FOMC pegs rate.
content: Wall Street was instantly cheered by the decision not to raise interest rates yesterday, writes Jane Martinson in New York. The blue chip Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 35.44 to 7,264.32 just five minutes after the decision was announced at 2.15pm New York time. However, the initial enthusism was tempered soon after. Analyst said this was partly due to fears of a July increase. The gains echoed those in the bond market, which saw an instant marked turnaround in sentiment after a lacklustre morning. Enthusiasm for equities overturned weak morning trading, during which the Dow had fallen by as much as 65 points. Analysts had been more than usually divided over the possible outcome of the FOMC meeting. Amid the uncertainty, Mr Warren Epstein, director of trading at Rosenblatt &Co, had played down the impact of the long-awaited decision. After an initial sell-off, he said, any decision to raise rates "might be seen as a positive", especially if economic data continued to show strong growth. Early trading in other markets was mixed. Technology stocks staged a fightback, allowing the technology-driven Nasdaq composite index to outperform the blue chips after a period of weaker growth. It rose 6.29 to 1,347.53 while the broader based S &P 500 fell 3.83 to 829.44. Financial blue chips to suffer from the Dow's uncertainty included J.P. Morgan, which fell 1.5% or $1 1/2 to $101, and Travelers Group which lost $1 or 1.8%, to $54 3/4. IBM continued to confound the blue-chip trend and echo other computer groups after a positive broker's note. It rose $2 1/8 or 1.3% to $170 7/8. Intel, also benefiting from upbeat research, helped the Nasdaq increase with a gain of $3 5/8 or 2.4% to $158 3/8. Informix fell $1/32 to $8 29/32 in some of the most active trading on Nasdaq as the market continued to take a negative stance on the troubled database company. A rally sparked by takeover speculation last week had failed to prevent the shares losing half their value in the past month. C-Cube Microsystems lost $5 3/8 to $20 1/8 as the company warned of lower than expected second-quarter earnings. TORONTO tracked Wall Street from the opening with leading stocks moving lower across a broad front. At noon, the 300 composite index was off 26.08 at 6,221.30. Most industrial sectors eased. Worries about a rise for US interest rates cast a cloud over the banks while golds found little comfort in a stable, but still weak bullion price. Bank of Montreal retreated 35 cents to C$52.80 and Royal Bank of Canada came off 45 cents to C$58.80. Among golds, Barrick shed 15 cents to C$33.40 while Placer Dome gave up 15 cents to C$25.15. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: US Treasuries jump as Fed sits tight.
content: The US Treasury market greeted the Federal Reserve's decision not to change interest rates with initial euphoria. However, this was quickly tempered by concern over whether future rate increases would need to be made. The benchmark 30-year bond, having risen to 96 3/4 within five minutes of the decision being made, fell at one point. Some 20 minutes after the announcement, the long bond was trading 1/32 higher at 96 9/32, yielding 6.910%. Fewer sellers hit the short end of the curve as the market celebrated the let-up in immediate tension. Earlier, US bond prices had dropped at mid-session as the market fell victim to nervousness ahead of the interest rate ruling. The 30-year benchmark bond had fallen by 3/16 to 96 1/16, yielding 6.933%. At the shorter end, the two-year note had been down 1/16 to 100 1/8, yielding 6.286%. Volume had been relatively low as traders waited for the Fed to announce its decision. Mr Kevin Logan, senior market economist at Kleinwort Dresdner Benson, had said "nobody wants to hold the risk on the day it could happen". The difference in yield between the two-year and 30-year note had already been hovering around its lowest levels for the year so far at about 65 basis points. Mr Logan had said this spread could fall to about 60 basis points with the yield for the benchmark bond rising back above 7%. Traders had suggested selling by hedge funds which have taken advantage of the strong dollar against the Japanese yen to buy shorter notes was also behind some of yesterday's downward pressure. European government bond markets trod water yesterday waiting for the outcome of the Fed committee meeting. FRENCH OATs were the only leading European bonds to give any ground, settling at the day's low of 129.64, down 0.24 on Monday's close. Analysts said there was little to explain the drift downwards. "There's been some profit-taking ahead of the FOMC. Some minor positions have been liquidated," said Mr Philip Tyson, European bond analyst at HSBC. "Other than that, everyone was content to remain on the sidelines." UK GILTS barely moved, in spite of a big turn-out for the auction of #1.5bn of 7% 2002 stock. Cover was 3.03 times and there was no yield tail. "We expected a tail of a couple of basis points so we were pleasantly surprised," said Mr Edmund Nonis, gilts analyst at Nikko Securities. The auction was small, however, and Mr Nonis warned about reading too much into it. The June long gilt future settled at 113 15/32, up 1/32 on the day. In the cash market the 10-year yield spread of gilts over bunds tightened 3 basis points to 142 points. Preliminary May inflation data from five Italian cities was in line with expectations and elicited few reactions from ITALIAN BTPs. Having jumped to 131.02, the June BTP future settled at 103.89, up 0.12 on the day. The 10-year yield spread of BTPs over bunds tightened 4 basis points to 137 points. May inflation figures from a further six Italian cities are due today. Yesterday's figures suggested that Italian annual inflation would slow to 1.5% in May, down from 1.7% in April, analysts said. Traders in SPANISH BONOS were taken aback by a late rally which coincided with the sudden rise in Italian BTPs. "I was a bit surprised ... maybe it was just one buyer," said Mr Jose Ramon Arechederra of ABN Amro in Madrid. Bonos eventually settled at 116.08, up 0.41 on the day. The 10-year yield spread of bonos over bunds touched a new low of 69 basis points before settling at 70 basis points. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: Dow rallies after Fed pegs rate.
content: Wall Street was cheered by yesterday's decision not to raise interest rates, writes Jane Martinson in New York. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed not far from its all-time high with a 74.58 increase to 7,303.46. The market had initially reacted with enthusiasm before falling off. Most of the gains were then made in the last hour of trading. Mr David Shulman, chief strategist at Solomon Brothers, echoed other bullish commentators when he said: "The Fed has given the green light to the stock market." The decision by the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, announced yesterday afternoon, had a more positive impact on stock prices than on the bond market, which was relatively muted. The benchmark 30-year bond rose 5/16 to 96 9/16 although it had fallen during the afternoon on fears about a rates increase in July. Other analysts believed that the Fed should have raised rates to slow recent fast growth. Mr Byron Wein, US strategist at Morgan Stanley, said: "The bond market is smarter than the stock market". He said it was too soon to say what the long-term effect of the decision would be, although he predicted a difficult summer. Analysts had been more than usually divided over the possible outcome of the FOMC meeting, although the bond market appeared to have factored in no change.<The enthusiastic response was widespread. The technology-driven Nasdaq composite index rose 22.64 or 1.7% to 1,363.88, while the broader based S&P 500 gained 8.39 to 841.66. Financial blue chips rallied strongly after the decision, having suffered from some uncertainty in morning trade. J.P. Morgan rose 2.7% to $105 1/4 while Travelers Group gained $1 7/8 or 3.4% to $57 7/8. IBM rose almost 3% or $4 3/4 to $173 1/2, helped by a positive broker's note. Ford, the motor giant, also benefited from rumours of an upbeat analysts presentation and the possibility of a share buy-back. It rose $1 or 2.8% to $37 3/8. Even Informix, the troubled database company which has lost almost half its share price value, rose 4% or $3/8 to $9 5/16 in the upbeat market. It had fallen sharply in recent weeks. However, C-Cube Microsystems lost 22% or $5 5/8 to $19 7/8 as the company warned of lower than expected second-quarter earnings. TORONTO closed higher after a late afternoon rally sparked by Wall Street. The 300 composite index rose 12.76 or 0.20% to 6,260.14. Declines slightly outpaced advances 482 to 475. Trading volume was 83.2m shares, down from Friday's total of 88.7m. Trading value rose to C$1.52bn from C$1.36bn. The golds sub-index weighed on the market, falling 0.34%. Franco Nevada slipped 45 cents at C$69.35. Bank of Montreal added 25 cents to C$53.40 and Royal Bank of Canada gained 15 cents at C$59.40. Not Available for Re-dissemination.

headline: Yen rises as Fed makes no move.
content: The dollar tumbled further late yesterday after the Federal Reserve left US interest rates unchanged following its Open Market committee meeting. The dollar, which had already fallen sharply in overnight Asian trading, immediately dropped another Y 0.75 on news of the meeting to stand at Y 112.95 against the yen. That was Y 3.25 below its Monday London close. The Fed's announcement sent the dollar falling 1.3 pfennigs against the D-Mark to DM 1.6860, 2.1 pfennigs down on Monday's close. The yen had surged even before the FOMC meeting, on fresh signs that Japan might raise interest rates soon. The currency jumped to Y 112 against the dollar after Mr Koko Sato, a senior member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic party, said there was growing political support for a rise in interest rates. Low rate levels were "negatively affecting pensioners and could also invite further fund outflow from the domestic financial market to high-yielding overseas assets." A panel of LDP politicians is due to issue a report within days which will indicate that the low rate climate may also be distorting the financial system. The Bank of Japan's official discount rate has stood at a record trough of 0.5% since September 1995. The markets largely ignored an attempt by Mr Taku Yamasaki, chairman of the LDP's policy research council, to play down Mr Sato's remark. Mr Yamasaki said now was not the time to discuss the possibility of a rate rise. Also yesterday, the Japanese trade union confederation said it would soon formally ask the Bank of Japan for a rate rise because low interest rates were hurting pensioners and savers. The dollar came under further pressure after Mr Robert Rubin, US treasury secretary, repeated that Washington's policy towards the currency was unchanged but failed to reel off his usual mantra that the US supported a strong dollar. The yen has now gained almost Y 15 or 12% against the dollar in the last fortnight, on hopes of a Japanese rate rise and attempts by Tokyo officials to talk down the dollar. The same officials are now trying to support the US currency. Yesterday Mr Eisuke Sakakibara, the senior finance ministry official known as Mr Yen, said: "The pace of the yen's strengthening is too rapid." Japan would "deal appropriately" with excessive volatility. That boosted the dollar somewhat. The dollar's slide buoyed the Swiss franc, largely because many traders had funded dollar purchases by borrowing the Swiss currency at low interest rates. The Swissie rose from SwFr 1.428 to SwFr 1.406 against the dollar, and from SwFr 0.837 to SwFr 0.830 against the D-Mark in London. * Mr Ron Leven, currency strategist at J.P. Morgan in New York, believes the dollar may stop sliding sooner than many in the market think. The reason, he says, is that many Japanese investors are hedging rather than selling their overseas assets. For instance, rather than disposing of their US Treasuries and repatriating the income, they are selling dollars forward. That means that if they change their view on the yen, they can return to overseas markets simply by buying dollars forward for the same period. "If the Japanese had left the US market completely, it would be much more difficult for them to come back in again," Mr Leven said. * Mr Paul Chertkow, head of global foreign exchange research at UBS in London, warned that the dollar could fall through support at Y 110 against the yen soon because the market no longer believed the US currency had much upside. The only way Japan could boost the dollar would be by changing policy, he said. Tokyo could hardly cut interest rates, so it would have to encourage Japanese life companies to increase their holdings of overseas assets again, and also to buy Japanese bonds in order to reduce their yields. If the dollar did bounce, many Japanese investors would quickly sell it in order to cut their losses on its recent slide, said Mr Chertkow. Not Available for Re-dissemination.
